column4: I installed OOo3 beta through using dpkg -i etc. How do I go about removing it the same way? dpkg -P *.deb refuses, as does xargs'ing searches to dpkg as well.
apt-get remove ...
Problem is I cant pass the filenames to apt, as it doesnt list it that way
don't use filenames - use the packagenames
I was hoping to not have to do that... as it'd be quicker and mean less guessing
it's quite simple if you can use grep and cut ..  apt-get remove $(apt-show-versions -r ^openoffice.org | grep -i "$VERSION_STRING" | cut -d "/" -f 1)

In this case it was quite easy, just apt-get remove ooobasis3-* and it pulled the depenencies etc. I still think it'd be nice if you could pass it through the original packages somehow... If I installed 500 packages and then wanted to remove them I'd be quite annoyed
well, you can always extract the actual package names from *.deb in a directory and then pipe that to apt-get. i believe dpkg-scanpackages does this
I dont seem to have dpkg-scanpackages, nor is it available in any repository... Cant seem to find a command that shows the package name like gdebi does, any other tips?
it's in the dpkg-dev package which should be installed by default
/usr/bin/dpkg-scanpackages
koshari : Wasnt installed by default on my 8.04 x64 at least.. But I'll give it a whirl now, cheers
heh, look what i overlooked.   for i in /path/to/*.deb; do dpkg-deb -W $i; done
perhaps this.  for i in *.deb; do dpkg-deb -f $i Package; done | xargs sudo apt-get remove
Yeah that would do it. Nice.... *notes down for later (ab)use* Thanks :)
i hate the way all these dpkg/apt tools are organised - there's too many of them all doing different things, hard to keep track of what does what
Well for a newbie like me it is at least... The logical way would be just to dpkg -i *.deb to install, and dpkg -r *.deb to remove. Not having it remove everything, from that directory
killall has a -u option that takes a username as an argument
Whats wrong with that? It works
your way is a hack.
Still, works :p
the tools remember the priorities of services when they are enabled/disabled
Fair enough
